fields: Positive and normative statements
A positive statement is a statement of fact. A normative statement is a statement of value or opinion.
Problem of scarcity
Scarcity arises from limited resources and unlimited wants. Choices have to be made due to this fundamental problem.
Opportunity cost, explicit and implicit

Opportunity cost is the expected benefits from the next best alternative that is forgone when making a decision. Explicit costs are costs that require a direct money payment, while implicit costs are the value of everything else that is sacrificed (e.g. time).
Marginal benefit and cost

Marginal benefit refers to the additional benefit derived from undertaking an additional unit of an activity. Marginal cost refers to the additional opportunity cost incurred when undertaking an additional unit of an activity.
Marginalist principle

At any given unit of an activity, if the marginal benefit exceeds the marginal cost, it is rational for the economic agent to undertake the activity, because the agent would gain more benefit than cost through this action. Otherwise, it is rational not to undertake it because the agent would incur more cost than benefit.
Law of diminishing marginal utility/revenue

As the consumer becomes more satisfied, each additional unit of the good consumed will give less additional utility than previous units. As the firm's output rises beyond a certain threshold, its marginal cost of production would start to increase as factors of production become more inefficient.
Production possibility curve

The production possibility curve shows all the maximum attainable combinations of two goods that a country can produce within a specified time period with all its resources fully and efficiently employed, at a given state of technology.
Market equilibrium

Market equilibrium refers to a situation in which buyers and sellers are on aggregate satisfied with the current combination of price and quantity of a good bought or sold and are under no incentive to change their present economic actions.
Market adjustment process

There is a surplus in the market since quantity supplied exceeds the quantity demanded, resulting in a downward pressure on the price. To sell the surplus, producers will begin to lower prices. As price falls, consumers are willing and able to buy more causing quantity demanded to increase. As price falls, producers will also be less incentivised to produce due to a fall in profitability, causing quantity supplied to decrease. This fall in price continues until the equilibrium price is reached.

There is a shortage in the market since ququantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied, resulting in an upward pressure on the price. Consumers will try outbid one another for existing supplies. As price increases, producers will be incentivised to produce more due to an increase in profitability. Due to the increased price, consumers will be less willing and able to buy, thereby causing quantity demanded to fall. This rise in price continues until the equilibrium price is reached.
Demand and law of demand

The demand for a commodity refers to the amount that consumers are willing and able to purchase at each given price over a period of time.

The quantity demanded of a good is inversely related to its price, ceteris paribus.
Income and substitution effects

The income effect occurs when a change in price of the good affects consumers' real income or purchasing power, which in turn affects consumers' ability to buy the good.

The substitution effect occurs when a change in price of the good causes consumers to switch to (or from) alternative products, which in turn affects the quantity demanded of the good.
Non-price determinants of demand (10)

Tastes and preferences
Seasonal/climatic changes
Expectations of future prices
Income (normal vs inferior good)
Prices of related goods (substitutes vs complements)
Derived demand
Government policies (direct tax vs direct subsidy)
Population
Interest rates
Exchange rates
Supply and law of supply

The supply of a good or service refers to the quantity of a good or service that producers are willing and able to offer for sale at each given price over a given period of time.

The quantity supplied is directly related to the price of a product.
Non-price determinants of supply (7)

Costs of production/Prices of factors of production
Innovation/State of technology
Natural factors
Number of firms
Government policies (indirect taxes vs indirect subsidy)
Prices of related goods (joint supply vs competitive supply)
Expectations of future price changes
Demand-supply graph
Consumer and producer surplus

Consumer surplus is the difference between the maximum amount that consumers are willing and able to pay for a given quantity of a good and what they actually pay, and measures consumer welfare.

Producer surplus refers to the difference between the amount received by producers for selling their good and the minimum prices that they are willing and able to accept for supply additional units of the good.
Functions of the price mechanism

Signalling (allocative) function
Rationing (distributive) function
Incentive function
Allocative and productive efficiency

Allocative efficiency is the situation in which the society produces and consumes a combination of goods and services that maximises its welfare.

Productive efficiency is achieved when all resources and fully and efficiently utilised.
Price elasticity of demand

Price elasticity of demand is a measure of the degree of responsiveness of the quantity demanded of a good to a change in its price, ceteris paribus.\[PED=\frac{\text{% change in quantity demanded}}{\text{% change in price of good itself}}\]Sign of PED is negative because of the inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded. Magnitude below 1 is price inelastic demand, at 1 is unitary price elastic demand, above 1 is price elastic demand.
Determinants of price elasticity of demand (4)

Number and closeness of its substitutes
Proportion of income spent on the good
Habituality of consumption
Time horizon
Price elasticity of supply

Price elasticity of supply is a measure of the degree of responsiveness of the quantity supplied of a good to a change in its price, ceteris paribus.â€Š\[PES=\frac{\text{% change in quantity supplied}}{\text{% change in price of good itself}}\]Sign of PES is positive because of the direct relationship between price and quantity demanded. Magnitude below 1 is price inelastic supply, at 1 is unitary price elastic supply, above 1 is price elastic supply.
Determinants of price elasticity of supply (5)

Level of stock or inventory
Availability of spare capacity
Mobility of factors of production
Time horizon
Length of production period
Cross elasticity of demand

Cross elasticity of demand is a measure of the degree of responsiveness of the quantity demanded of a good to a change in the price of another good, ceteris paribus.\[CED=\frac{\text{% change in quantity demanded of good A}}{\text{% change in price of good B}}\]Sign of CED is positive when the two goods are substitutes, negative when the two goods are complements. Magnitude indicates the strength of the relationship, the closer the substitutes/complements, the greater the magnitude.
Income elasticity of demand

Income elasticity of demand is a measure of the degree of responsiveness of the quantity demanded of a good to a change consumers' income, ceteris paribus.\[YED=\frac{\text{% change in quantity demanded}}{\text{% change in income}}\]Sign of YED is positive when the good is a normal good, negative when the good is an inferior good. Magnitude indicates the strength of the relationship between income and the demand for the good. Normal goods with YED less than 1 is classified as a necessity, more than 1 is classified as a luxury.
Limitations of elasticity concepts (4)

Computation issues
Issues with prediction
Cost concerns
Ceteris paribus assumption
Direct and indirect taxes

Direct taxes are taxes on income and wealth and are paid to the tax authorities directly by the economic agent with the income/wealth. This affect the willingness and ability of households to consume goods and services and leads to a shift of the demand curve.

Indirect taxes are taxes on goods and services that are paid to the tax authorities indirectly by the suppliers of the goods and services. A specific tax is an indirect tax of a fixed sum per unit sold (parallel shift), while an ad valorem tax is an indirect tax of a certain percentage of the price of the good (pivotal shift).
Direct and indirect subsidies

Direct subsidies are subsidies granted by the tax authorities directly to the economic agent with the income/wealth. This affect the willingness and ability of households to consume goods and services and leads to a shift of the demand curve.

Indirect subsidies are subsidies granted by the tax authorities indirectly to the suppliers of the goods and services. A specific subsidy is an indirect subsidy of a fixed sum per unit sold (parallel shift), while an ad valorem subsidy is an indirect subsidy of a certain percentage of the price of the good (pivotal shift).
Price and quantity controls

Minimum price/price floor is a legally established minimum price to prevent prices from falling below a certain level. The price floor must be set above the market equilibrium price.

Maximum price/price ceiling is a legally established maximum price to prevent prices from rising above a certain level. the price ceiling must be set below the market equilibrium price.

A quota is a limit on the quantity produced imposed by the government through legislation and regulation. The quantitative restriction must be set below the market equilibrium quantity.
Objective of firms (4)

Profit maximisation
Revenue maximisation
Profit satisificing
Market share dominance
Short and long run

Short run is a time period during which at least one factor of production is fixed. Output can increase only by using more variable factors.

Long run is a time period long enough for all inputs to be varied, except the level of technology.
Fixed and variable cost

Fixed cost is a cost that does not vary with output level. It is a cost that must be paid even when production does not take place.

Variable cost is cost that varies with output level. It is not incurred when production does not take place.
Short run cost graph
Long run average cost graph
Internal economies of scale (3)

Technical economies of scale
- Factor indivisibility
- Law of increased dimensions (the container principle)
- Specialisation and division of labour
Financial economies of scale
- Lower interest rate and larger loans
- Raise capital through bonds
Marketing economies of scale
- Bargaining advantage
- Bulk advertising and large-scale promotion
Internal diseconomies of scale (2)

High cost of monitoring and management
Low morale of employees
External economies of scale (2)

Economies of information
- Common research and development knowledge
Economies of concentration/agglomeration economies
- Availability of skilled labour
- Well-developed infrastructure
External diseconomies of scale (2)

Increased strain on infrastructure
Shortage of industry-specific resources
Supply side factors for size of firms (3)

MES at low levels of output relative to market
Saucer shaped LRAC
Banding and joint ventures
Demand side factors for size of firms (4)

Nature of the product
Market segmentation and specialization
Geographical factors
Profit cycles
Other factors for size of firms (2)

Unwillingness to take greater risks
Profit satisficing objective
Market structures (4)

Perfect competition
Monopolistic competition
Oligopoly
Monopoly
Perfect competition (4)

Large number of buyers and sellers
No barriers to entry and exit
Homogenous product
Perfect knowledge (price taker)
Monopoly (4)

Single producer
Complete barriers to entry and exit
- Artificial barriers (strategic barriers, statutory barriers)
- Natural or structural barriers to entry
- Barriers to exit (sunk costs)
Unique product - no close substitutes for the product
Imperfect knowledge
Monopolistic competition (4)

Large number of small buyers and sellers relative to market size
Low barriers to entry and exit
Differentiated products
- Real physical differences
- Imaginary differences
- Differences in conditions of sale
Imperfect knowledge
Oligopoly (4)

A few dominant firms relative to market size
High barriers to entry
- Artificial barriers (strategic barriers, statutory barriers)
- Natural or structural barriers to entry
Products can be homogenous or differentiated
Imperfect knowledge
Oligopoly cooperative and competitive model (4)

Cooperative model (collusion)
- Cartels
- Price leadership

Competitive model
- Price rigidity
- Price wars
Pricing strategies (3)

Uniform pricing
Price discrimination
Price competition
Price discrimination and conditions (3)

Price discrimination occurs when a producer sells the same good at different prices whereby the price difference does not reflect differences in the cost of supplying the customer.

The seller must have market power.
The firm must be able to identify and segment the market according to differences in price elasticity of demand (customer characteristics, location, past purchase behaviour).
The firm must be able to prevent resale and abitrage.
Price discrimination benefits and limitations (6)

Capture consumer surplus
Consumers who are more price sensitive will be able to enter the market
Produce in cases where cost of providing a good or service cannot be covered by the low revenue generated

Price discrimination is only if firms are successful in segmenting the market and preventing resale
Price discrimination can create opportunities for the resale market to grow.
Price competition (4)

Predatory pricing
Price wars
Limit pricing
Discounts
Non-price strategies (6)

Product differentiation
Advertising
"Free gifts with purchase" promotion
Customer loyalty rewards programs
Research and development
Green and ethical marketing
Cost-reducing strategies (6)

Source for cheaper inputs
Increase scale of production
Band together or set up jointly owned enterprises
Cluster in together for economies of concentration
Develop existing and new business processes
Offshoring stages of production to another country
Growth strategies (2)

Mergers and acquisition
- Horizontal integration
- Vertical intergration (forward integration, backward integration)
- Diversification/Conglomeration
Franchising
Cognitive biases (3)

Saliency bias - focus on salient features to cause irrational decision-making
Loss aversion bias - prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains
Sunk cost fallacy - stick with a strategy that they already invested heavily
Market failure
Market failure is defined as the failure of the free market to achieve an efficient allocation of resources that maximises the society's welfare.
Sources of market failure (5)

Externalities
Information failure
Zero provision of public goods
Market dominance
Immobility of factors of production
Positive/negative externalities from production/consumption

The self-interested consumers/producers are only concerned with the private benefits of [...], and would ignore external benefits/costs of [...]. The presence of these marginal external benefit/cost causes a deviation of marginal society benefit (MPB+MEB) from the marginal private benefit curve. The free market equilibrium is where MPB=MPC, which is higher than societal optimal quantity where MSC=MCB. The overconsumption/underconsumption of [...] units result in deadweight/welfare loss represented by ABC. For each additional unit consumed/produced more/less than equilibrium, [...].
Information failure (2)

Imperfect information
Asymmetric information
- Adverse selection
- Moral harzard
Public goods
Public goods are goods that are non-rivalry in consumption and non-excludable. They also exhibit characteristic of non-rejectability.
Immobility of factors of production (2)

Occupational immobility
Geographical immobility
Forms of government intervention (3)

Taxes and subsidies
Legislation and regulation
- Legislation/laws
- Quota
- Tradeable permits system
Direct provision of goods
- Goods under-consumed/produced
- Public goods
Market dominance measures (6)

Reducing barriers to entry
Anti-trust (anti-monopoly) laws
Regulations on standards of provision
Price regulation
- Marginal cost pricing
- Average cost pricing
Lump-sum tax
Nationalisation
Information failure measures (2)

Education and campaigns
Laws to address asymmetric information
Government failure (6)

Unintended consequences not addressed
Imperfect information
Bureaucracy and inefficiency of government intervention
Time lags
Shifts in government policy
Rent seeking
Macroeconomic aims (4)

Economic growth
Price stability
Full employment
Favourable balance of trade position
Actual and potential economic growth

Actual growth is the increase in national output actually produced for a given period of time, commonly measured by the percentage increase in real GDP.

Potential growth is the increase in the productive capacity of the economy for a given period of time. An increase in quantity or quality of resources will contribute to potential economic growth.
Fundamental identity of national income

National product (value of all goods and services produced in an economy) equals national income (total income earned by workers in an economy) equals national expenditure (total expenditure by consumers in an economy).
Gross domestic product, real and nominal

Gross domestic product is the value of all final goods and services produced within the geographical boundary of a country over a given period of time

Real GDP is the value of final goods and services produced in a given year expressed in terms of the prices in a base year.

Nominal GDP is the value of the final goods and services produced in a given year expressed in terms of the prices in that same year.
Gross national income

Growth national income measures the value of all final output of goods and services produced by nationally owned factors of production during a given period of time, using the income approach.

GNI = GDP + NFIA (net factor income from abroad)
Limitations of GDP/GNI (2)

Presence of non-market activities
Presence of underground economy
Price stability
Price stability results from a low and stable rate of inflation. This means that prices increase gradually and do not fluctuate in wild and unpredictable manners.
Consumer price index and inflation rate

Consumer price index measures the price of a fixed basket of goods and services commonly purchased by a typical household.

Inflation rate measures the change in price level from year to year, and is measured in percentages. It is calculated as (CPI (current year) - CPI (previous year))/(CPI (previous year)) * 100%.
Limitations of CPI (2)

Substitution bias
Quality adjustment bias
Full employment

Full employment indicates a non-zero, low rate of unemployment that is compatible with price stability, when all those who are able and willing to work have gained employment. At full employment, structural and frictional unemployment can still occur.
Limitations of unemployment rate (2)

Unemployed people stop looking for jobs and leave the labour force
Size of the labour force increases but people are not immediately employed
Accounts in the balance of payment (3)

Current account
- Trade balance (goods, services)
- Income balance (primary income, secondary income)
Capital and financial account
- Direct investment
- Portfolio investment
Reserve assets account
Material standard of living

Material standard of living can be indicated by the quantity of goods and services consumed by the average person in a country in a given time period. It is typically measured using real GDP per capita.
Limitations of real GDP per capita (2)

Income distribution
Composition of GDP
Non-material standard of living

Non-material standard of living refers to the qualitative aspects of life. It can be measured using real GDP per capita or other welfare indicators.

Healthcare
Education
Pollution
Stress level
Security
Limitations of welfare indicators (2)

Relationship between real GDP per capita and non-material welfare is unclear
Welfare indicators are subjective because welfare cannot be quantified
Purchasing power parity

Purchasing power parity is a theory of exchange rates whereby a unit of any given currency should be able to buy the same quantity of goods in all countries. It accounts for differences in cost of living when comparing material welfare between countries.
Limitations of PPP-adjusted real GDP per capita (4)

Difficulties in determining the basket of goods
Difference in consumption patterns based on context of countries
Difference in accounting procedures
Omission of non-marketed transactions
Circular flow of income
Aggregate demand

Aggregate demand refers to the total level of spending for an economy, based on the amount of domestically produced goods and services which households, firms, government and foreigners desire to buy, at each general price level.
Wealth, interest rate and international subsitution effects

The wealth effect occurs when the general price level falls, causing the purchasing power of households to increase.

The interest rate effect occurs when the general price level falls, causing households to require less money to purchase a given quantity of goods and services. Given a fixed supply of money, a fall in demand of money would cause interest rates to fall. A lower interest rate encourages borrowing by households for consumption on interest sensitive items.

The international substitution effect occurs when the domestic general price level falls while foreign prices remain constant, causing domestically produced goods to become cheaper relative to foreign substitutes. Residents are likely to demand less foreign goods. Foreigners are likely to purchase more of this country's goods.
Autonomous and induced consumption

Autonomous consumption refers to consumption that is independent on the current level of real national income.

Induced consumption refers to consumption that is dependent on the current level of real national income.
Non-price determinants of aggregate demand for consumption (5)

Economic outlook and consumer confidence
Interest rates and access to credit
Distribution of income
Wealth
Personal income taxes
Non-price determinants of aggregate demand for investment (4)

Interest rates and access to credit
Business confidence and expectations
Corporate tax rates
Technology changes
Non-price determinants of aggregate demand for net exports (4)

National income of trading partners/domestic households
Relative price levels between countries
Exchange rates
Trade policies - protectionism
Marginal efficiency of investment

According to the marginal efficiency of investment theory, there is an inverse relationship between interest rate and investment. The MEI refers to the expected rate of return (or income or profit) of an additional unit of investment while the rate of interest refers to the cost of borrowing.
Aggregate supply
Aggregate supply refers to the total value of output of goods and services that domestic firms as a whole produce and sell at each general price level.
Non-price determinants of aggregate supply (5)

Changes in input prices
Changes in quantity of resources
Changes in quality of resources
Technological advancements
Government policies
Multiplier

Multiplier is a numerical coefficient by which a change in autonomous spending is multiplied to show the final change in equilibrium national income.\[k=\frac{\Delta NY}{\Delta AD}\]Î”NY is change in equilibrium national income
Î”AD is change in spending\[k=\frac{1}{MPS+MPT+MPM}=\frac{1}{MPW}=\frac{1}{1-MPC}\]MPS is the marginal propensity to save
MPT is the marginal propensity to tax
MPM is the marginal propensity to import
MPW is the marginal propensity to withdraw
MPC is the marginal propensity to consume
Multiplier effect

With an increase in [...], there will be an equivalent increase in aggregate demand. The AD curve shifts to the right from AD1 to AD1a. To meet this rise in AD, firms affected wil need to produce more output and hire more factors of production. Firms will pay out income to the factors of production in return for the output produced. Hence, real national income will increase from Y1 to Y1a.

Households spend a proportion of this increase in income on buying domestically produced consumer goods and services (based on MPC). This increase in induced consumption causes AD1a to rise to AD1b. Again, in response to rising AD, production and thus income increases. This second round of income induced further consumption, and subsequently increasing AD and income again.

However, this process does not continue infinitely because of the presence of withdrawals in the form of savings, taxes and import expenditure. This causes the additional increase in spending and income to be a fraction of the previous addition to the circular flow, and the rightward shifts in the AD curve becomes smaller and smaller in each successive round. Eventually when the cumulative sum of withdrawals equals the initial increase in autonomous AD, the multiplier process will stop.

The initial rise in AD has resulted in a more than proportionate rise in real national income, the multiplied increase in real national income represents actual economic growth.
Limitations of multiplier effect (4)

Size of multiplier k
Level of spare capacity in the economy
Time lags
Difficulties in measurement
Aggregate demand-supply graph
Sustained and inclusive economy growth

Sustained economic growth requires both actual and potential growth.

Inclusive economic growth indicates a rate of growth that is sustained over a period of time, is broad-based across economic sectors, and creates productive employment for the majority of the country's population.
Benefits and costs of economic growth (6)

Higher current and future standards of living
- Higher material standard of living
- Higher non-material standard of living
Decrease in demand-deficient (or cyclical) unemployment
Higher capacity for redistributing income and helping the poor

Overheating economy and demand-pull inflation
Unequal and inequitable distribution of income
Negative externalities and environmental costs
Causes of weak economic growth (6)

Fall in aggregate demand
Lack of fixed capital investment
Lack of/fall in quantity and quality of natural resources
Lack of investment in human capital
Lack of technological advancement
Structural rigidities
Consequences of weak economic growth (5)

Higher unemployment
Lower standard of living and savings
Slower long term economic growth rates due to pessimistic outlook
Lower inflation rate
Influences on the balance of payments position
Types of unemployment (3)

Demand-deficient/cyclical unemployment
Structural unemployment
- Changes in pattern of demand
- Foreign competition (or changes in comparative advantage)
- Changes in technology and occupational immobility
- Geographic immobility
Frictional unemployment
Consequences of unemployment (4)

Forgone output or income in the economy and lower living standards
Strain on government budget
Social problems
Hysteresis (applies to demand-deficient unemployment)
Inflation and types of inflation (3)

Inflation is a situation where there is a sustained increase in the general price level.

Mild/low inflation
Galloping inflation
Hyperinflation
Causes of inflation (2)

Demand-pull inflation
Cost-push inflation
- Inflation due to exhaustion of raw materials
- Import-induced inflation
- Wage-push inflation
- Profits-push inflation
- Tax-push inflation
Benefits of low and stable inflation (6)

Promotes investment and economic growth
Promotes international competitiveness and improve the BOT and BOP
Promotes sustained economic growth and lower unemployment
Economic agents can take actions to protect themselves to maintain current and future standard of living
Improve efficiency in resource allocation
Increases the leeway for monetary policy
Costs of high and unstable inflation (8)

More difficult to protect material standard of living
Reduces investment which hinders potential economic growth
Reduces international competitiveness and worsens the BOP
Difficulty in sustaining economic growth
Arbitrary redistribution of income worsening income distribution
- Fixed income earners vs variable income eaners
- Workers in strong trade union vs workers in weak trade union
- Debtors vs creditors
- Holders of financial assets vs those with physical or real assets
Significant "menu costs"
Hinders efficient resource allocation
Wage-price spiral causing a breakdown in the functions of money
Deflation and causes of deflation (2)

Deflation occurs when there is sustained decrease in general price level, i.e. negative rate of deflation.

Causes of deflation are fall in aggregate demand and increase in aggregate supply.
Consequences of deflation (3)

A deflationary spiral can develop which affects economic growth and employment
Deflation can increase the real burden of debts
Deflation is harder to solve than inflation
Exchange rate and types of systems (3)

Exchange rate is the price of one country's currency in terms of another currency or a basket of foreign currencies.

Free float exchange rate system
Fixed exchange rate system
Mannaged float exchange rate system
Consequences of exchange rate stability (4)

Reduction in uncertainty about exchange rate can lead to improvement in capital/financial account and promote sustained economic growth
Fixed exchange rate regimes can often lead to severe financial crises because they are difficult to maintain in the long run
Foreign reserve accumulations also entail opportunity costs
Fixed exchange rate regimes can also be inflationary if the domestic country tries to maintain an exchange rate below the free market exchange rate
Causes of balance of trade deficit/surplus (5)

Changes in global conditions
- Cyclical changes in global demand
- Sustained economic growth in the importing country
Changes in international competitiveness
- Changes in comparative advantage
- Changes in taste and preference
- Changes in relative inflation rates between countries
Changes in exchange rates
Government policies
Random factors/shocks
Consequences of balance of trade deficit (3)

Implications on economic growth and standard of living
Implications on equity
Opportunity costs
Consequences of balance of trade surplus (3)

Implications on economic growth and standard of living
Accumulation of foreign exchange reserves
Possible retaliation by trade partners
Fiscal policy
Fiscal policy is the deliberate management of government spending and taxation designed to influence the level of economic activity to achieve the economic goals of the government.
Marginal and average tax rate

Marginal tax rate is the proportion of additional income paid in taxes.\[MTR=\frac{\text{Change in tax paid}}{\text{Change in income}}\]Average tax rate is the proportion of total income paid in taxes.\[ATR=\frac{\text{Total tax paid}}{\text{Total income}}\]
Types of taxes (3)

Proportional tax
Progressive tax
Regressive tax
Economic effects of taxes (5)

Incentive to work (labour supply)
Savings
Investments
Inflation
Resource allocation
Economic effects of government expenditure (3)

Income and wealth redistribution and standard of living
Economic growth
Resource allocation
Discretionary fiscal policy and types (2)

Discretionary fiscal policy refers to a deliberate change in government expenditure and/or taxes to bring about the desired change in the level of AD.

Expansionary fiscal policy is used to boost economic growth and other economic indicators (increase government expenditure, reduce taxes).

Contractionary fiscal policy is used to curb excessively high aggregate demand that brings about inflationary pressures (reduce government expensiture, increase taxes).
Non-discretionary fiscal policy

This is an automatic fiscal policy that checks or stimulates economic activities, not by any deliberate government action, but by the operation of built-in or automatic stabilisers. Examples are progressive tax structure, unemployment compensation and family assistance programme.
Effects of fiscal policy (5)

Economic growth and employment
- Actual growth and employment
- Potential growth
- Inclusive economic growth
- Sustainable economic growth
- Standard of living
Inflation
Balance of trade
Income distribution
Resource allocation
Limitations of expansionary discretionary fiscal policy (8)

Size of multiplier
Role of consumer and business confidence
Problem of time lags
- Recognition lag
- Administrative lag
- Operational lag
Crowding out effect
- Crowding out of domestic private investment
- Crowding out in an open economy
Sustainability of running a budget deficit
- Choice of instruments
- Large and persistent budget deficit vs cyclical deficit
Conflicts with other macroeconomic objectives
- Trade-off with internal aims
- Trade-off with external aims
Role of expectations
Other limitations
- Inflexibility
- Political pressures from lobby groups
Limitations of contractionary discretionary fiscal policy (4)

Role of expectations and confidence
Conflict with other macroeconomic aims
Inflexibility
Undesirable impact on economic growth and standard of living
Limitations of non-discretionary fiscal policy (2)

Adverse supply-side effects
Problem of fiscal drag
Monetary policy and types (2)

Monetary policy refers to the actions of a central bank to influence the availability of credit (money supply), cost of credit (interest rates), or value of its currency in the foreign exchange market (exchange rate), to achieve macroeconomic goals.

Monetary policy can be expansionary or contractionary.
Effects of monetary policy (3)

Internal effect
External effect
Impact on real national income, employment and inflation
Limitations of expansionary monetary policy (6)

Interest elasticity of demand for investment
Expectations of the future state of the economy
Liquidity trap
Time lags between implementation and impact on the economy
Inability to achieve specific macroeconomic objectives
Unintended consequences: conflicts with other macroeconomic aims
Limitations of contractionary monetary policy (2)

Short/long term basis of projects
Conflicts with other economic goals
Marginal efficiency of investment curve
Supply-side policies and types (2)

Supply-side policies are designed to improve structural performance of an economy, to improve the productive capacity of an economy by increasing the quantity, quality and mobility of factors of production in an economy.

Supply-side policies can be market-oriented or interventionist.
Market-oriented supply-side policies (5)

Privatisation
Pro-competition policies
- A tougher competition policy regime
- Deregulation/liberalisation
- Promoting freer trade between nations
Reducing the power of trade unions
Tax cuts
- Effects on labour supply
- Effects on capital accumulation
Cuts in welfare benefits
Interventionist supply-side policies (5)

Education and training
Grants to encourage research and development
Encourage small business start-ups/entrepreneurship
Nationalisation
Other labour market policies
- Income policies (wage guides/flexible wages/wage freeze)
- Wage subsidies
Effects of supply-side policies (4)

Growth and inflation
- Inclusive economic growth
- Sustainable economic growth
Employment
Balance of trade and balance of payments
Standard of living
Limitations of supply-side policies (4)

Depends on accuracy and availability of information to government
Trade-offs (exacerbating income inequalities)
Difficult or unfeasible due to limited fiscal budget
Policy acceptability (politically unpopular policies)

note_models.name: A Levels
